title: Orewiler is athlete of month
text:
Orewiler is athlete of month Denny McPherson , Reporter 7:01 p.m. EDT October 22, 2015 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CALEDONIA - River Valley senior golfer Caden Orewiler made a change to his game, but it was one of the mental variety. 
That change led the Fahey Bank’s Male Athlete of the Month for September to a consistent and quality season. 
The son of Amy and the late Chuck Orewiler, of Waldo, Orewiler said he was disappointed with how his season ended in a district tournament. 
Yet he was low man in just about every match he played this fall to dominate the area prep golf scene. 
“I changed my patience,” Orewiler said. “I did not meet my expectations last year, and my swing never felt the same. 
“I talked to my mom about staying patient, and my game took off.” 
Orewiler came out of the chute with a 68 for 18 holes to win the North Union Invitational. He followed with rounds of 70 at the Marion Country Club in the Marion City/County Invitational and a 69 in the Mid Ohio Athletic Conference Tournament at Oakhaven Golf Club to place first in both of those tournaments. 
Orewiler attributed his hot start to a fine summer, especially in one event. 
“I won a tournament in Chicago (the GolfWeek Midwest Invitational at Cog Hill) late in the summer, and I felt real confident,” Orewiler said. “I also knew I had a great group of guys around me at River Valley, so I had no worries teeing it up.” 
Orewiler, a four-time winner of the Fahey Bank award, was then medalist in 9 of 14 events to conclude his regular season. He averaged 35.1 strokes per nine-hole round this season. 
Up next was the sectional tournament at Oakhaven, and Orewiler won it with a nifty score of 67. 
“I felt like I could have played better,” he said. “I missed a couple of 10-foot birdie putts.” 
He went on to district play, where only the district champion advanced to the Division II state tournament. 
Orewiler shot a 71 at the Denison Golf Club in Granville, but that was only good enough for a tie for first place. Orewiler then finished second in the event by losing in a playoff for first place. 
“I knew what I had to do at the district, but I fell just short,” he said. “It sucked, but that’s life.” 
Orewiler was nonetheless pleased with the fact he gave himself a chance to advance. 
“I didn’t have my A game, but I stayed patient and I stayed close until the end,” he said. “It’s something you have to accept and move on.” 
Orewiler played in the state tourney a year ago, and he lamented the fact he couldn’t return this year. 
“I looked forward to that. Winning a state championship was another thing on my list to get,” Orewiler said. “Growing up, the state championship was it for me. I feel like there is something missing.” 
He’ll try to find that when he moves on to play college golf under scholarship at Ohio State University. 
“I have high school records and a district player of the year award, but maybe there is something bigger out there,” Orewiler said. “I will play golf with great guys from across the country in college, and then I will see where my golf game is. I’ll know where I stand after college.”
